title: 107_s2844
content: The Act may be cited as the "Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a need for 2,000,000 new teachers in the next decade. The No Child Left Behind Act requires States to recruit qualified teachers by 2006, but schools in rural and high-poverty areas struggle to attract and retain teachers. Rural education is crucial for overall education performance. The Trust 2000 report emphasizes the importance of rural education in 25 States for overall education performance. High poverty schools face challenges in teacher certification, requiring special assistance to meet the goals of the No Child Left Behind Act. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards was established in 1987. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, founded in 1987, aims to establish high standards for accomplished teachers. Over 16,000 teachers from all 50 states and the District of Columbia have completed certification. Recent data from the Accomplished Teaching Validation Study show that teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards outperform non-certified peers on 11 of 13 key teaching measures. Teacher salaries have stagnated over the past decade, with 2/3 of states not meeting the national average of $40,582. The purposes of the Act include encouraging teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools through a refundable tax credit and providing an additional tax credit for National Board certification. The Act aims to encourage teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools by offering a refundable tax credit and providing an additional tax credit for National Board certification. The Act offers a tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural schools and certified teachers. The Act provides a tax credit for eligible teachers in rural areas or high poverty schools, based on the applicable amount for the academic year. The Act offers a tax credit of $1,000 for eligible teachers in public schools where at least 75% of students receive free or reduced-cost lunches. The Act provides a tax credit of $1,000 for eligible teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards in schools with a School Locale Code of 7 or 8, or in rural areas. For eligible teachers in schools with high poverty or in rural areas, the applicable amount is $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as a kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher in a public school on a full-time basis. The section defines eligible teachers as kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers in public schools on a full-time basis for an academic year ending after December 31, 2002. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
